div.p: S. D. I am very delighted by your lengthy letters, esteemed lord and dearest brother.
I, however, always write briefly.
But please be understanding, especially now, as I have been bedridden for over 14 days and still am with completely exhausted strength.
I received your letter written on July 1st and shared it with the brothers.
We are always eager to hear good news about the affairs of the French churches.
You did not write unfortunate news; we expect happier news, indeed we pray to the Lord, that He may be with us and thwart the bloody plans of the adversaries.

I would indeed be pleased if you would compile commonplaces from the books of Mr. Peter Martyr, and indeed briefly and composed in a didactic order; if anyone else can accomplish this, you can especially.
I do not think our printers can justly complain, as this seems to be a new work.
Mr. Martyr wrote very elegant commentaries on the books of Kings, which Mr. Froschauer will soon publish; these will be useful especially for your purpose.

But first, I think the commentaries on 3 Kings should be published, then what remains on the 4th book; finally, the commentaries on the books of Samuel will be added; now the commentaries on Aristotle's Ethics are being printed.
I am eagerly awaiting what you will write about the French affairs and that English war, whether it is pacified or continues.
I see amazing things being woven by the Roman pontiff and his advisors; I would therefore wish those English, Danish, and Swedish wars to be pacified.
We will pray to the Lord, that He may be with His church and scatter the bloody plans of the adversaries.
I commend to you these Polish students; one is Wenceslaus Ostrorog, son of a very great and pious man in Poland.
Greet Mr. Crispin, Mr. Badius, and other good men; all of ours greet you.
Farewell.
Zurich, July 26, 1563.
Your Bullinger.
To the most illustrious man Mr. Théodore de Bèze, most faithful minister of the Geneva church, esteemed lord and my dearest brother.
Geneva.
